segments.text: So, the code reads an integer n, then reads n entries of four integers each into a 2D array called vec.
segments.label: code_analysis

segments.text: Then, for each entry, it checks if there's another entry that has all three components (the first three elements) greater than the current one.
segments.label: code_analysis

segments.text: If not, it considers that entry as a candidate and selects the one with the smallest price (the fourth element).
segments.label: code_analysis

segments.label: code_analysis

segments.text: In Fortran, I'll need to use READ statements.
segments.label: language_mapping

segments.text: Also, Fortran uses static arrays, so I need to declare them with a fixed size. But since n is read from input, maybe I should first read n, then allocate the array dynamically.

segments.text: Wait, Fortran 90 and later support allocatable arrays. So I can read n first, then allocate the vec array as (n,4) or (4,n)? Let me see.

segments.text: The Java code uses vec[i][0], vec[i][1], etc., so each row is a record.

segments.label: code_analysis

segments.text: Let's define vec as a 2D array with dimensions (n,4), where each row represents a computer's specs.
segments.label: high_level_plan

segments.text: Then, for each i from 1 to n, check if there's a j where vec(i,1) < vec(j,1), vec(i,2) < vec(j,2), and vec(i,3) < vec(j,3).
segments.label: code_analysis

segments.text: If any such j exists, then the current i is outdated.
segments.label: code_analysis

segments.text: So, we only consider the ones that are not outdated, and pick the one with the smallest price.
segments.label: high_level_plan

segments.text: In Fortran, loops are written with do loops.
segments.label: language_mapping

segments.text: So, for i in 1 to n, set a flag fl to 1 (true), then loop j from 1 to n. If any j satisfies the three conditions, set fl to 0.
segments.label: high_level_plan

segments.text: After checking all j, if fl remains 1, check if the price is the minimum so far.
segments.label: high_level_plan

segments.text: Also, the Java code uses 0-based indices, but Fortran uses 1-based by default. So the loop variables will start at 1.
segments.label: language_mapping

segments.text: The answer is the original index (i+1 in Java, which becomes i in Fortran if the loop is 0-based).
segments.label: code_analysis

segments.text:
Wait, in the Java code, for each i (0-based), if it's not outdated, then compare its price. The answer is stored as ans = i + 1. So in Fortran, since loops are 1-based, the index i (from 1 to n) would directly correspond to ans = i. So, the steps in Fortran:

1. Read n from input. 2.
segments.label: language_mapping

segments.text: Allocate vec as a 2D array of size (n,4).
segments.label: high_level_plan

segments.text:
3. Read each of the n lines into vec(i, 1:4) for i from 1 to n.

4. Initialize ans and ansprice.
segments.label: high_level_plan

segments.text: In Java, ans starts at 500 and ansprice at 20000, which are larger than any possible inputs (since price is up to 2000 in the problem statement?

segments.label: high_level_plan

segments.text: Wait, the Java code initializes ans to 500 and ansprice to 20000, which are probably higher than possible values.
segments.label: code_analysis

segments.text:
Then, for each candidate, if the price is lower than ansprice, update ans and ansprice. So in Fortran, we can start with ansprice as a very large value (like 2e5) and ans as 0. Then, loop over each i from 1 to n:

   fl = 1

   loop j from 1 to n:

      if vec(i,1) < vec(j,1) and vec(i,2) < vec(j,2) and vec(i,3) < vec(j,3), then set fl=0 and exit the j loop. if fl == 1:

      if vec(i,4) < ansprice:

          ansprice = vec(i,4)

          ans = i

So, the answer is the index i (1-based) of the candidate with the smallest price.
segments.label: code_analysis

segments.text:
Wait, the fourth component in the Java code is vec[i][3], which is the price. So in Fortran, if the array is (n,4), then for the i-th row, the price is vec(i,4). So, in Fortran, the code would have:

do i = 1, n

   fl = 1

   do j = 1, n

      if (vec(i,1) < vec(j,1) .and. vec(i,2) < vec(j,2) .and. vec(i,3) < vec(j,3)) then

          fl = 0

          exit  ! exit the j loop early

      endif

   end do

   if (fl == 1) then

      if (vec(i,4) < ansprice) then

          ansprice = vec(i,4)

          ans = i

      endif

   endif

end do

But in Fortran, the logical operators are .and., and the syntax is different. Now, handling input. How to read the input?
segments.label: language_mapping

segments.text: The input for each line is four integers: speed, ram, hdd, price.
segments.label: high_level_plan

segments.text:
In Java, for each i in 0..n-1, reads four integers into vec[i][0], vec[i][1], vec[i][2], vec[i][3]. So in Fortran, for each i from 1 to n, read vec(i,1), vec(i,2), vec(i,3), vec(i,4). But in Fortran, when reading from standard input, each read statement typically reads a line. So perhaps read each line as four integers. In Fortran, we can read using:

do i = 1, n

   read(*,*) vec(i,1), vec(i,2), vec(i,3), vec(i,4)

end do

Yes.

Putting this together. So the Fortran program structure would be:

program main

    implicit none

    integer :: n, i, j, fl, ans, ansprice

    integer, allocatable :: vec(:,:)

    read(*,*) n

    allocate(vec(n,4)) do i = 1, n

        read(*,*) vec(i,1), vec(i,2), vec(i,3), vec(i,4)

    end do

    ans = 0

    ansprice = 20000  ! as in Java code

    do i = 1, n

        fl = 1

        do j = 1, n

            if (vec(i,1) < vec(j,1) .and. vec(i,2) < vec(j,2) .and. vec(i,3) < vec(j,3)) then

                fl = 0

                exit

            end if

        end do

        if (fl == 1) then

            if (vec(i,4) < ansprice) then

                ansprice = vec(i,4)

                ans = i

            end if

        end if

    end do

    print *, ans

end program main

But according to the code logic, if there's at least one candidate (fl==1), then ansprice would be updated. So if no candidates exist (which is impossible since if all are outdated, but for each i, there exists j where all three are larger, but then j must have a j' even larger, leading to a contradiction), but perhaps in code, the initial ansprice is 20000. So in Fortran, the same initial ansprice.

But according to the problem's logic, there must be at least one candidate (since for each computer, if there's a newer one, that's a j, but then that j could be checked again. But in reality, the code will have at least one candidate.

Okay, I need to translate this Java code to Fortran. Let me start by understanding what the Java code does. 

So, the code reads an integer n, then reads n entries of four integers each into a 2D array called vec. Then, for each entry, it checks if there's another entry that has all three components (the first three elements) greater than the current one. If not, it considers that entry as a candidate and selects the one with the smallest price (the fourth element). The answer is the index (starting at 1) of that entry.

Hmm, Fortran has different syntax and structures. Let me think about how to structure this.

First, input handling. In Java, they use Scanner and read from System.in. In Fortran, I'll need to use READ statements. Also, Fortran uses static arrays, so I need to declare them with a fixed size. But since n is read from input, maybe I should first read n, then allocate the array dynamically.

Wait, Fortran 90 and later support allocatable arrays. So I can read n first, then allocate the vec array as (n,4) or (4,n)? Let me see. The Java code uses vec[i][0], vec[i][1], etc., so each row is a record. In Fortran, column-major order is default, but maybe it's easier to have vec(4, n) where each column is a record. Or maybe (n,4) as rows. Let's see. Let's define vec as a 2D array with dimensions (n,4), where each row represents a computer's specs.

Then, for each i from 1 to n, check if there's a j where vec(i,1) < vec(j,1), vec(i,2) < vec(j,2), and vec(i,3) < vec(j,3). If any such j exists, then the current i is outdated. So, we only consider the ones that are not outdated, and pick the one with the smallest price.

In Fortran, loops are written with do loops. So, for i in 1 to n, set a flag fl to 1 (true), then loop j from 1 to n. If any j satisfies the three conditions, set fl to 0. After checking all j, if fl remains 1, check if the price is the minimum so far.

Also, the Java code uses 0-based indices, but Fortran uses 1-based by default. So the loop variables will start at 1. The answer is stored as ans = i + 1. So in Fortran, since loops are 1-based, the index i (from 1 to n) would directly correspond to ans = i.

Then, loop over each i from 1 to n:

   fl = 1

   loop j from 1 to n:

      if vec(i,1) < vec(j,1) and vec(i,2) < vec(j,2) and vec(i,3) < vec(j,3), then set fl=0 and exit the j loop.

   if fl == 1:

      if vec(i,4) < ansprice:

          ansprice = vec(i,4)

          ans = i

So, the answer is the index i (1-based) of the candidate with the smallest price.

Wait, the fourth component in the Java code is vec[i][3], which is the price. So in Fortran, if the array is (n,4), then for the i-th row, the price is vec(i,4).

So, in Fortran, the code would have:

do i = 1, n

In Java, for each i in 0..n-1, reads four integers into vec[i][0], vec[i][1], vec[i][2], vec[i][3]. So in Fortran, for each i from 1 to n, read vec(i,1), vec(i,2), vec(i,3), vec(i,4).

program main

    implicit none

    integer :: n, i, j, fl, ans, ansprice

    integer, allocatable :: vec(:,:)
